webTitle: BAE poised to cut jobs in Portsmouth and Scotland

fields.standfirst: More than 1,000 jobs at risk as defence contractor copes with the end of shipbuilding boom
fields.body:
BAE Systems is preparing to close its Portsmouth shipyard in an overhaul of its naval manufacturing operations that will put more than 1,000 jobs at risk on England's south coast and in Scotland.

The government and Britain's largest defence contractor are preparing to announce a restructuring of BAE's yards in Portsmouth as well as at Scotstoun and Govan in Glasgow, with statements due to be made later this week. .

It is understood that there will be a commitment to the future of shipbuilding on the river Clyde – a politically sensitive issue with the 2014 Scottish independence referendum looming – but there will still be job losses at the two Scottish sites, which employ 3,200 people.

However, ship construction is widely expected to cease at Portsmouth naval base, where 1,200 employees have worked on building hull sections for the HMS Queen Elizabeth and HMS Prince of Wales aircraft carriers.

The cuts come after BAE Systems has experienced the biggest peak in UK shipbuilding since the second world war, led by the £5.4bn aircraft carrier programme that that saw BAE share its allocation of the work across Portsmouth, Govan and Scotstoun. The next BAE project for the Royal Navy, the Type 26 combat ship, is not big enough to sustain all three sites.

Discussions about the restructuring have been taking place for more than a year between the Ministry of Defence (MoD), BAE Systems and trade unions.

BAE declined to be drawn on the potential job losses. "We continue to work closely with the MoD to explore all possible options to determine how best to sustain the capability to deliver complex warships in the UK in the future. This work is ongoing and we are committed to keeping our employees and trade unions informed as it progresses," the company said.

Hugh Scullion, general secretary of the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions, said: "We have secured talks with senior BAE systems executives early next week to examine the business case of the forthcoming announcement. The shipbuilding workforce throughout the UK are working flat out to deliver the aircraft carriers for the defence of the UK and they need to know what lies in store for them, their families and their communities."

The first of the carriers, Queen Elizabeth, is due to begin sea trials towards the end of the decade. A decision will not be taken until 2015 about whether the second carrier, Prince of Wales, will ever be operational; it could be sold or mothballed. The carriers were built by a consortium that included BAE.

The MoD said how BAE "rationalise their business" is a matter for the company. "Negotiations between the MoD and the Aircraft Carrier Alliance regarding the rebaselining of the Queen Elizabeth carrier programme are at an advanced stage," it said. "No final decisions [on the programme] have been taken."

If shipbuilding is wound down at Portsmouth, the MoD will have to bear costs that could run into hundreds of millions of pounds under a 2009 agreement guaranteeing BAE a minimum of £230m a year in shipbuilding and support work over 15 years. The agreement can be cancelled, but the MoD would be liable for closure costs and compensation to BAE for its lost investment.

An additional 2,900 BAE staff are employed in the Portsmouth area on tasks that include maintaining, servicing and upgrading the Royal Navy ships at the naval base. Their jobs are not expected to be affected by the announcement.

The future of the last major shipbuidling sites on the Clyde, a former powerhouse of the global shipping industry, is set to become a talking point of next year's referendum, with any threatened closure of the Scotstoun or Govan sites expected to benefit the independence campaign.

Scotland's finance secretary, John Swinney, said: "We have been in dialogue for some time with BAE Systems on the issues surrounding the future of the Clyde shipyards. We are awaiting the outcome of BAE's discussions with the MoD and are very alert to the situation concerning both yards. We are seeking urgent clarity on the future for both Govan and Scotstoun."

webTitle: Ryanair's new touchy-feely O'Leary hits turbulence but sees clearer air ahead

fields.standfirst: Controversial airline's chief admits mistakes but says firm had to change after 'running like lunatics' for 20 years
fields.body:
Strange things are afoot at Ryanair. Shareholders have complained about the airline's image. Profits are set to dip for the first time in five years. The ever-rising share price has finally tumbled. And chief executive Michael O'Leary, the man the flying public most loves to hate, has embraced customer service. Investors have been posing a previously unthinkable question. Has O'Leary screwed up?

In the wake of a second profits warning that saw about £30m wiped off his own personal paper wealth in Ryanair shares, O'Leary admits he made mistakes and will be imitating easyJet in reshaping his company. There will be a year of "evolution" after "running like lunatics" for the last two decades of extraordinary growth.

The airline is making changes, as O'Leary put it, to: "Stop unnecessarily pissing people off." It is ending the scramble to board, relaxing baggage policy, toning down onboard selling and softening penalties for customer errors. But it is the apparent culture change – to "new, cuddly Ryanair" – that has grabbed the headlines.

"If I'd known it was going to generate this much free PR, I'd have done it years ago," says O'Leary, 52, who in a strategy based on ferocious cost control has played the jester-cum-villain throughout Ryanair's ascent.

"An awful lot of what I did over the years is generate lots of cheap, free publicity, because we're in the business of generating cheap, free publicity.

"When you're growing rapidly it's enough to be able to just open up new routes, make noise – charge you for toilets, standing room, we'll adopt any measure going as long as it generates fucking cheap publicity, banning people from charging mobile phones. Grand. We'd go at almost anything.

"Now we're not opening up new markets, actually that's the wrong message. Now we need to address those repeat flyers and say look, better on-time performance than ever, better customer service, we're addressing those issues you wanted to address … We're listening to you. We're responding to your needs, God help me. The Robin Hood fucking stuff does need to change. We need to move away from making noise and actually start communicating with people."

For all that he courted the publicity, some of the bad press belatedly rankles. "There's enormous imbalance in a lot of the coverage we get. Why are we carrying 81 million passengers if we're this terrible? Yes, we have the lowest fares, we have brand new aircraft, we have the most on-time flights – it sounds like kind of a fucking Mormon, Moonie session – but we do."

The allegedly gentler Ryanair first emerged in July when shareholders at the annual meeting in Dublin complained that the airline's image was costing it and the chief executive admitted responsibility for a "macho culture" that had to change.

Now, though, O'Leary claims the change of tack in the airline he has run since 1994 was due less to shareholder concerns than an inevitable stage in Ryanair's progress, as it awaits the first deliveries of 175 new planes from Boeing.

"We opened up seven new bases last year. There'll be almost no new bases this year. OK, so what makes news this year? The great thing was this focus on customer service, O'Leary's Sauline conversion, me apologising for my character flaws. The AGM: one guy asked one question: why do you fight, why are we fighting so many people?

"You'd swear the AGM went on for three days of interaction. But if that's the appetite in the media, for those kind of stories, we'll run with it. Ryanair on Google news – it's all fucking Damascene conversion, Sauline conversion. I guess we were torturing people for the last 20 years."

Yet there will be, he insists, fundamental changes to the business model. "It'll have to evolve, be a different Ryanair. It can't always be cheeky fucking chappie and in your face. We've been running like fucking lunatics for the last 20 years. So, a bit of pause: what needs to be addressed?"

"We've had an approach to the website that it's cheap, way cheaper than the competition so people will still put up with almost any amount of irritation – 17 bloody clicks to book a ticket, and yet 81million people still book a ticket. But that's not acceptable. He admits that in luring business passengers and in online booking facilities, Ryanair had slipped behind easyJet. But now? "Anything easyJet can do, we can do better and cheaper … if we get all these issues addressed, we start taking new aircraft next September, start expanding, there will be new routes. We build a bigger, better Ryanair." That will include flying to more city centre airports rather than distant airfields – another advantage long claimed by easyJet.

So did he get it wrong? "I think I made lots of small mistakes. But we're good at actually identifying where we're going wrong and checking back. Anyone who says he doesn't make mistakes is a fool. You can't not make mistakes in this business, 'cos you're always trying things.

"It was easier to be dismissive of some of those things because we were growing so fast. It doesn't matter. More routes, new aircraft, low fares. Pile them high, flog 'em cheap."

O'Leary, having previously derided social media, recently took enthusiastically to Twitter. "It allows us to interact better with our customers, and understand genuinely what annoys them and what doesn't," he says. Barely a year ago, he notoriously dismissed the half million people on Facebook who backed a customer's complaint over a boarding pass reissue charge of several hundred euros by calling it "her fuck-up". Now, though, he says: "We do need to improve. One of the things we've been very conscious of with the Spanish and some of the Italian handling agents, this kind of rubbish: the baggage fits but the wheels stick out. For fuck's sake, it gets on. Stop fighting with people over bullshit like a handle sticking out." Didn't those strictures come from O'Leary? "Absolutely not. I wish I had that power to issue edicts and they were automatically followed."

Yet analysts say nothing happens at Ryanair without O'Leary's stamp. Andrew Lobbenberg of HSBC says: "It's a business run by firm edict from the top."

At some level, it is clear that O'Leary, for all his talk of feedback, does not entirely accept his airline still has a problem with customer service.

Bringing up a recent Which? survey that named Ryanair the worst brand for customer service, O'Leary fulminates: "I think you have to have enough cop on to say look that survey's irrelevant. Yet it keeps being peddled, Ryanair's the most hated brand. What the hell are you surveying? 99% of people don't think what's my favourite brand, they look for the cheapest fares. If Which? surveys were the way forward, BA would be booming."

Much customer dissatisfaction is "apocryphal and anecdotal", he claims, saying the airline responds to complaints in seven days. "Things go wrong for very few people flying Ryanair. But what we do is exactly what BA do. I see far more British Airways passengers stranded at Heathrow when they had the snow last year … Does BA ferry them all to local hotels? No they don't! They're all sleeping in the terminal." (A BA spokesman said that in fact the airline paid in full for transfers and accommodation.)

O'Leary adds: "BA have warehouses all over Europe of lost bags that they can't redeliver to anybody. We don't." (BA: "Absolute rubbish.")

Nor has O'Leary's attitude to passengers entirely changed. "I guarantee 90% of negative feedback will come from people who are in breach of the policies they agreed to abide by. It's not that we want your money, we don't want your bloody gate bags. Show up with a 55 by 30 by 20 and you're fine, you're on. Stop whining afterwards if you show up with a suitcase that's bigger than that."

While the boarding pass reissue fee will be cut to £15, the £70 charge for not checking in online stays: "Because you broke the rules. If you don't turn up at the airport without a passport, why the hell do you show up without the boarding pass?"

O'Leary breaks off for a TV news interview, having his Remembrance Day poppy adjusted. Is this poppy-wearing part of the new O'Leary? He looks briefly, genuinely cross. "In percentage terms far more fucking Irish guys were killed in the two world wars than English guys. I always wear them."

So is O'Leary's own position in doubt? HSBC's Lobbenberg tips shares to bounce back up and rise further, saying that moves to imitate easyJet, however clumsy, are overdue and will bear fruit.

Douglas McNeill, investment director at Charles Stanley said: "They'll still make a half billion of euros this year in profit, they've three billion of cash in the bank and score highly on many things that customers care about. There are a lot of airline bosses who would kill to have the problems Ryanair has." He believes being a successor to O'Leary would be tough but added: "He, like the company, does have to reinvent his image a bit. That can't be accomplished quickly. "

So can O'Leary embody the change in an airline moulded in his image – and has he changed personally? "I think so. I've learned how to use the Twitter."

Rumours of retirement from the job are unfounded; he is, he says: "Loving it. There's no vacancy at the moment."

webTitle: Letters: Why is it taboo to restore public utilities?

fields.body:
Seumas Milne, in his splendidly argued case for public ownership of basic utilities and services (The private grip on essential services has to be broken, 30 October), says that in spite of popular support "it's taboo in the political mainstream". We have to ask why.

Apart from the need to keep their corporate backers happy and the revolving doors open for when they retire from office, politicians cannot dream of supporting, protecting and developing public services. To do so would be to return to a bureaucratically run state economy. Death to innovation and enterprise. They clearly do believe that.

Mariana Mazzucato, in The Entrepreneurial State, Debunking Public vs Private Sector Myths, documents how the state played a crucial role in some landmark innovations of our time and makes "an open call to change the way we talk about the state, its role in the economy, and the images and ideas we use to describe that role". It would be hard, if not impossible, for David Cameron and George Osborne to read and learn, but Ed Miliband and Ed Balls could.
John Airs
Liverpool

• Privatisation of utilities had a two-pronged purpose: primarily, to remove borrowing requirements from the national debt to adhere to EC rules; second, to provide piles of wonga for government coffers. It's obvious that each was flogged off on the cheap: just look at current share prices. Why is it that several other European governments found innovative ways around this problem? The chief method was forming standalone companies able to borrow money in their own right. In the main, these companies are majority-owned government assets. The supreme irony is that they are able to take over UK utilities, repatriating profits, thus subsidising their domestic operations. So we, the British public, subsidise many of our continental cousins. Who was the brainbox who allowed this to happen?
Ian Lowery
Kensworth, Bedfordshire

webTitle: Primark sales surge boosts owner ABF

fields.bodyText: Must-have budget fashion and bigger stores have triggered a surge in sales and profits at Primark this year. The retail chain, which is part of the Associated British Foods group, saw a 22% rise in revenues to £4.27bn in the year to September, boosting underlying profits by 44% to £514m. Like-for-like sales, stripping out the impact of new store openings, rose 5%, a marked difference to the slip at bigger rival Marks & Spencer, which is struggling to attract younger shoppers into its clothing aisles. "Primark continues to take off like a rocket, but the turnaround of Marks & Spencer continues to be a bit of damp squib," said Nick Bubb, an independent retail analyst. While M&S pointed to a market heavily reliant on discounting during an unseasonably warm autumn, Primark said its autumn/winter ranges were selling well with few promotions after a strong summer helped by great weather. It added that sales of the autumn/winter range in the new financial year were encouraging with strong demand particularly for slim-fitting chinos, zip hoodies and tartan fashions. Shoppers were spending even in Ireland, where M&S is closing stores. George Weston, chief executive of ABF, said it was a remarkable year for the fashion retailer and prospects for the future looked good. Primark has stocked up on novelty Christmas jumpers after selling out last year but still expects its famous onesies to sell well again. Weston said sales of onesies were doing particularly well in Germany where 11 of the top 15 stores for onesie sales were located. "We think its going to be another onesie Christmas," he said. Primark's performance comes despite having no online store after abandoning a test with internet fashion specialist ASOS earlier this year. Weston said the trial had proved it was very difficult to make money online at Primark's price points. He said: "I think we can compete on the high street with others selling online. Our business model is not being undercut by cheap clothes on the internet." While other fashion chains are trimming their high street estates, Primark is adding more than a million square feet of selling space in the new financial year, with 13 store openings planned in time for this Christmas, including five in Spain and its first store in France, which will open in Marseille. The continued success of Primark comes despite its links to the Rana Plaza factory collapse in Bangladesh in April, which killed more than 1,100 workers. A Primark supplier occupied the second floor of the eight storey building. Weston said that Primark had placed its last order with such "multi-use" factories and was working closely with other retailers in the Accord on Fire & Building Safety in Bangladesh to ensure safety at its 80 factories there. ABF's group revenue rose 9% to £13.3bn for the full year, while pre-tax profit rose 15% to £876m.

Must-have budget fashion and bigger stores have triggered a surge in sales and profits at Primark this year.

The retail chain, which is part of the Associated British Foods group, saw a 22% rise in revenues to £4.27bn in the year to September, boosting underlying profits by 44% to £514m.

Like-for-like sales, stripping out the impact of new store openings, rose 5%, a marked difference to the slip at bigger rival Marks & Spencer, which is struggling to attract younger shoppers into its clothing aisles.

"Primark continues to take off like a rocket, but the turnaround of Marks & Spencer continues to be a bit of damp squib," said Nick Bubb, an independent retail analyst.

While M&S pointed to a market heavily reliant on discounting during an unseasonably warm autumn, Primark said its autumn/winter ranges were selling well with few promotions after a strong summer helped by great weather.

It added that sales of the autumn/winter range in the new financial year were encouraging with strong demand particularly for slim-fitting chinos, zip hoodies and tartan fashions. Shoppers were spending even in Ireland, where M&S is closing stores.

George Weston, chief executive of ABF, said it was a remarkable year for the fashion retailer and prospects for the future looked good.

Primark has stocked up on novelty Christmas jumpers after selling out last year but still expects its famous onesies to sell well again.

Weston said sales of onesies were doing particularly well in Germany where 11 of the top 15 stores for onesie sales were located. "We think its going to be another onesie Christmas," he said.

Primark's performance comes despite having no online store after abandoning a test with internet fashion specialist ASOS earlier this year. Weston said the trial had proved it was very difficult to make money online at Primark's price points.

He said: "I think we can compete on the high street with others selling online. Our business model is not being undercut by cheap clothes on the internet."

While other fashion chains are trimming their high street estates, Primark is adding more than a million square feet of selling space in the new financial year, with 13 store openings planned in time for this Christmas, including five in Spain and its first store in France, which will open in Marseille.

The continued success of Primark comes despite its links to the Rana Plaza factory collapse in Bangladesh in April, which killed more than 1,100 workers. A Primark supplier occupied the second floor of the eight storey building.

Weston said that Primark had placed its last order with such "multi-use" factories and was working closely with other retailers in the Accord on Fire & Building Safety in Bangladesh to ensure safety at its 80 factories there.

ABF's group revenue rose 9% to £13.3bn for the full year, while pre-tax profit rose 15% to £876m.
fields.trailText: Associated British Foods boss calls it a 'remarkable year' after fashion retailer's revenue jumps by 22% to £4.27bn

webTitle: Marc Bolland's plan for M&S is a journey without a timetable

fields.standfirst: At 15.5 times this year's expected earnings, the latest rating reflects a lot of hope in the autumn-winter collection
fields.body:
Marc Bolland got burned when he set three-year sales targets for Marks & Spencer soon after arrival in 2010 -- he had to reduce the goals after a single lap of the track. So he is not about to be suckered into a game of predicting when M&S's general merchandise sales, down for nine quarters in a row on a like-for-like basis in the UK, will turn upwards.

Even so, the chief executive's latest plea for patience took vagueness to an extreme: "This is a journey on quality and style that will take a few collections to get a positive momentum behind it."

In other words, it's a journey without a timetable. For the time being, shareholders are asked to be satisfied that same-store general merchandise sales declined by 1.3% in the second quarter, not as weak as the 1.6% fall experienced in the first quarter.

The surprise, though, is that investors do seem to be satisfied. The share price rose 4% to regain 500p on Tuesday and, in the wings, new 3% shareholder Bill Adderley, respected founder of homeware chain Dunelm, is singing Bolland's praises. Why is everybody so cheerful in the face of a 9% fall in half-year profits to £262m?

One answer is that Bolland's broad strategy seems to be correct and M&S' difficulties are at least confined to clothing. The food side continues to buzz (like-for-likes sales up 3.2% in the second quarter). Meanwhile, the capital spending extravaganza, designed to bring M&S's IT and distribution systems into the 21st century, runs to budget. M&S confirmed that capital expenditure will fall from £775m to £550m next year, giving credence to the boast that a "material" improvement in cash flow lies around the corner.

So, yes, if clothing can be cracked, M&S could start to look pretty again. But, at 15.5 times this years' expected earnings, the rating reflects an awful lot of hope the much-hyped autumn/winter collection marks a real turning-point. Maybe it will, but when even the boss is talking about only a "step by step" improvement in clothing sales, caution is the best policy. At M&S, it often is.

webTitle: Co-op bank admits failing to attract customers switching accounts

fields.standfirst: Bank makes admission in documents released to encourage bondholders to back rescue plan to plug £1.5bn capital shortfall
fields.body:
Co-operative bank has admitted losing out in the war to attract customers switching current accounts, striking another blow to the government's attempts to foster competition on the high street.

The bank – in the throes of receiving a £1.5bn lifeline from hedge funds and the wider Co-op group of supermarkets, funeral homes and pharmacies – said there had been a "material reduction" in the number of people moving their accounts to it since the seven-day switching service was introduced in September. Co-op said its rivals had been advertising the new service heavily.

In thousands of pages released to encourage bondholders to back the rescue package, the Co-op also admitted it is likely to design share-based bonus schemes for its bosses after its shares are floated on the stock market next year. The Co-op Group is to give up full ownership of the bank under the rescue deal.

The bank also warned that it could face a significant VAT bill once the group's ownership falls to 30%. This is because it has service arrangements with the group.

Because of its ethical policy, the Co-op bank has been regarded as a major competitor to the big four – Lloyds Banking Group, Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays and HSBC – and a potential winner from the rapid switching service which promises to move a current account in seven working days without any errors.

Euan Sutherland, the boss of the Co-op Group, has said the bank's 4.7 million customers have remained loyal since the announcement in June that it had been ordered by the Bank of England to find extra capital to bolster its financial strength. The Co-op bank lost £1.4 bn in deposits from corporate customers after its credit rating was downgraded to junk status in May.

The former chairman of the bank, the Rev Paul Flowers, is likely to face questions from MPs about assertions in the 2012 annual report that the bank's financial position was strong, just weeks before regulators unearthed the £1.5bn capital shortfall. He is due to appear before the Treasury select committee on Wednesday.

The Co-op Group said it was co-operating with the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) and the accounting body the Financial Reporting Council (FRC) which are looking at the bank's statements about its capital position in the report. The group made clear inquiries are at a preliminary stage and it is not a formal investigation. The FCA declined to elaborate, while the FRC said: "We are making inquiries into the Co-op's financial reporting in accordance with our normal procedures. If we commence a formal investigation we always issue a press announcement."

A group of bondholders - which hold class of bond known as upper tier 2 bonds – have come out in support of the complex rescue offer, which if it fails could force the bank into the control of the Bank of England and possibly nationalisation. Holders of 15% of such bonds have said they back the offer.

webTitle: G4S debacles down to undermining of firm's values, says new boss

fields.bodyText: The new boss of embattled security group G4S has accused the company's former management of "undermining" the firm's values and contributing to a string of high-profile debacles such as last year's notoriously mis-managed Olympics contract. The comments were made as chief executive Ashley Almanza attempted to spell out why the group should not bow to activist shareholders and split up the company. After extensive changes at the top over the past year, he said, the company would stick to its existing strategy. Almanza said: "The company has got values. One of the reassuring things … is that the employees understand the core values and they are committed to those values. They are deeply committed to customer service, but as a whole, I don't think as a management team we always applied those values in a concentrated way … I think from time to time it has caused us to take actions that have undermined some of our core values." Almanza cited the debacle over last year's contract to handle security at the London games, when the army and police were drafted in to fill the gaps left by G4S's failure to provide enough security guards. The high-profile embarrassment has not been an isolated case, with other crises at the company including a current Serious Fraud Office criminal investigation into allegations of overcharging on electronic tagging contracts for offenders; a South African maximum security prison being taken over by local authorities after allegations that G4S staff "lost effective control of the facility"; and, most controversially, July's ruling that G4S security guards unlawfully killed Angolan deportee Jimmy Mubenga three years ago. Former chief executive Nick Buckles survived the Olympics debacle, as well as an aborted £5.2bn bid for Danish cleaning company ISS in 2011, but finally left the company in May with a £1.2m payoff after the company issued a profit warning. He was replaced by Almanza, who had only joined from BG Group three weeks earlier as chief financial officer. In his first five months in the role, the new chief executive said he had travelled around the world visiting distant parts of the company, which operates in more than 120 countries and has around 620,000 employees. But, despite the range of problems to have emerged at G4S, he concluded that there was no need for major changes to the business plan. "The core strategy's unchanged. The core service lines are unchanged and our market positions are unchanged," he said, before adding that senior management had been overhauled and the company would now "execute" differently. "We have a new chairman, we have a new chief executive and a new chief financial officer. We have three new independent directors on the board – all effectively in the last 12 months or so. So six of the 11 main board directors are new. In the executive team, we have five changes to our [11] executive committee positions." Almanza announced plans to sell or restructure 35 poorly performing businesses, which generated around £400m of G4S's £7.3bn revenue last year and have lower profit margins than the rest of the group. Any proceeds from sales are earmarked for investment in emerging markets, which are growing more quickly. The company also revealed that it would be cutting 250-400 UK jobs, out of around 45,000, as part of a "previously announced £30-35m restructuring programme". Cevian Capital, a £5bn activist investment fund, has recently emerged as a major G4S shareholder, increasing speculation in the City that Almanza is coming under pressure to dispose of G4S's troubled cash business. That division – which provides services such as replenishing cash machines and accounts for about 18% of the group's revenues – has attracted an approach from Charterhouse Capital, although G4S quickly rejected the offer on the grounds that the price of £1.55bn was too low and that the unit was strategically vital to the group and not for sale.

webTitle: Global financial crisis hit happiness and trust in governments – OECD

fields.standfirst: Average life satisfaction declined by more than 20% in Greece, 12% in Spain and 10% in Italy, according to research
fields.body:
The global financial crisis hit happiness and eroded trust in governments, according to the OECD thinktank.

Its research into the human cost of the crisis found that between 2007 and 2012, reported average life satisfaction declined by more than 20% in Greece, 12% in Spain and 10% in Italy.

"In the wake of the crisis, household income and wealth, jobs and housing conditions deteriorated and have not completely recovered yet in many OECD countries," says the How's Life report.

"This had the effect of increasing poverty and inequalities, especially among young people and low-skilled workers. The number of discouraged workers and inactive people has increased, as did perceived work-life conflicts for employed people. Clear negative trends have also emerged in subjective well-being and civic engagement, with increasing levels of stress, lower life satisfaction and decreasing trust in national governments."

The percentage of people in the worst affected euro area countries claiming to trust national government fell by 10 percentage points in the five years leading to 2012. In the 34 OECD countries as a whole, less than half of those surveyed said they trusted their governments – the lowest level recorded since 2006.

The thinktank's research into Greece suggests the average Greek household has been "severely affected" by the crisis, particularly when it comes to household income, jobs, life satisfaction and civic engagement.

From 2007 to 2011, Greece recorded a cumulative decline in real household disposable income of around 23%, the largest decline among the OECD countries. Between 2007 and 2010, income inequality increased by 2%, well above the OECD average of 1.2%.

The poor employment situation had a major impact on life satisfaction. From 2007 to 2011, the percentage of Greek people declaring being very satisfied with their lives fell from 59% to 34%, the lowest share in the OECD area.

The percentage of Greek people reporting that they trust the government fell from 38% to 13% between 2007 and 2012.

Over the same period, for many countries new forms of solidarity and engagement have emerged, the OECD said. But that trend was not evident in Greece, where the percentage of people reporting having helped someone and having volunteered their time decreased by 4 and 3 percentage points, respectively, between 2007 and 2012.

"Compared with other OECD countries, Greece performs well in only a few of the 11 dimensions that the OECD considers as essential to a good life," the report said.

"Greece ranks above the OECD average in the dimensions of health status, work-life balance and personal security, but below average in education and skills, income and wealth, civic engagement, jobs and earnings, social connections, housing, subjective well-being and environmental quality."

In the US, the pressures of unemployment over the crisis saw around 20% of households move in with other households, the OECD said. Life satisfaction also dropped in there. From 2007 to 2012, the percentage of American people declaring being very satisfied with their lives fell from 78% to 67%.

The percentage of American people reporting that they trust the government fell from 39% to 35% between 2007 and 2012.

webTitle: Eurozone growth forecasts trimmed, as personal well-being slides - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• Britain's service firms report strong growth in October 
• But EC cuts eurozone's 2014 growth forecast to 1.1%
• Payday loan firms blasted at parliament
• Photos: protests in Athens
fields.body:
5.16pm GMT

Time for a closing summary:

•  The European Commission lowered its growth forecast for the eurozone next year

• Stock markets fell in Europe after the EC downgrade

•  A new OECD report on 'well-being' showed it sharply lower in Greece, Spain and Italy, but Britain scored highly

• Britain's service firms posted their strongest growth in 16 years. 

• MPs heard that payday lenders are targeting young children with their TV adverts.

• Greece's government began the latest round of talks with its lenders over its bailout programme.

• Insiders say the Troika will also push for changes at Greece's defence industry, and could demand that two loss-making firms are closed

• Photos: protests in Athens

And on that note, it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all the comments, and we'll be back tomorrow.

5.09pm GMT

European markets have closed, and it has indeed been a downbeat day, not helped by the European Commission lowering its growth forecast for the eurozone, and lingering concerns about when quantitative easing will end. The closing scores were:

• The FTSE 100 finished 16.78 points or 0.25% lower at 6746.84

• Germany's Dax was down 0.31% at 9009.11

• France's Cac closed 0.82% lower at4253.34

• Italy's FTSE MIB ended down 1.13% at 19,091.93

• Spain's Ibex lost 0.79% to 9795.7

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently down 0.13% or 19 points.

4.13pm GMT

As we head to the close, markets are still falling back. Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

[In Europe] the mining sector has been the best performing sector today after Chinese HSBC services data pointed to a fairly constructive outlook for the Chinese economy in the short term.

But this hasn’t been enough to keep equity markets higher, as the EU downgraded its growth forecasts for the euro area in 2014, while German car maker BMW has helped drag the DAX lower after profits fell back.

US markets opened lower this morning taking their lead from today’s weakness in Europe as investor’s exercised caution ahead of some key data later this week.

It would appear that US markets are reluctant to push higher while investors absorb the different statements from various Fed policymakers,

Updated at 4.13pm GMT

3.57pm GMT

Here's a good piece by economist Shaun Richards about the challenges facing the European Central Bank as it prepares for its monthly meeting on monetary policy.

He runs through the various options facing the ECB to address falling inflation, lacklustre growth and stubbornly high unemployment. 

We are experiencing an era where politicians mostly delegate economic policy to central banks who have emerged blinking into the light from the shadows where in my view they belong. Why have they done this?

Well in a perversion of President John F Kennedy’s famous statement about going to the Moon they have delegated the job because it is hard, rather than being inspired. 

More here: Will the European Central Bank panic on Thursday?

3.47pm GMT

Photos: Protests in Athens as troika talks begin

Back in Greece...troika officials faced angry protests as they left the finance ministry after their first meeting with the Greek government, hours after coins were thrown at IMF mission chief Poul Thomsen as he arrived.

There were scuffles between demonstrators and police as Thomsen and colleagues left the meeting with finance minister Yannis Stournaras.

Many of the protestors were ministry cleaners who face dismissal as part of Greece's cuts to its public sector.

Associated Press reports that the Troika officials had to be spirited out of the building through an emergency exit, after protesting civil servants blocked the lifts and main entrance to the ministry.

They had earlier tried to disrupt the meeting by chanting anti-austerity slogans outside the room where it took place 

Updated at 4.06pm GMT

3.16pm GMT

America's service sector has followed Britain's by reporting that activity picked up pace in October, although the increase wasn't as dramatic.

The ISM survey of service sector activity rose to 55.4, from 54.4 in September, showing activity picked up. Firms also hired more workers. But there were also signs that last month's government shutdown did hit firms, with the new orders index dropping to its lowest level since July.

(a reminder - the UK service sector PMI hit 62.5 in October, the highest level since May 1997)

2.49pm GMT

Date for the diary - Italian Senators will vote on November 27 on whether to expel centre-right leader Silvio Berlusconi from parliament over his conviction for tax fraud, officials said (via Reuters).

2.47pm GMT

A late lunchtime summary

Time for a round-up of the main events of the day so far.

• The European Commission has lowered its growth forecast for the eurozone next year, predicting that GDP will rise by just 1.1% in 2014, not 1.2%. The EC's latest Autumn Forecasts also predicted weak growth and above-target deficits in several countries worst hit by the eurozone crisis.

Commissioner Olli Rehn said Europe had begun growing again, adding it was too early to claim "victory" in the financial crisis. He also warned that Slovenia must work hard to clean up its banking sector, Key points from Rehn's press conference are here.

The EC also predicted that inflation will remain subdued at 1.5% in 2014 and 1.4% in 2015, adding to pressure on the European Central Bank to ease monetary policy.

• The OECD has also flagged up the personal harm caused by the crisis. A new report found that 'well-being' has dived by 20% in Greece and is also sharply lower in Spain and Italy. Britain, though, scored pretty highly on its measure of places to live.

• Britain's service firms have posted their strongest growth in 16 years. Activity in the dominant sector rose by the highest rate since Tony and Cherie strolled through Downing Street in May 1997. City economists say it shows the UK economy is growing strongly at present.

• MPs have heard that payday lenders are targeting young children with their TV adverts, and causing a sharp rise in debt problems, at a hearing into the industry.

• Greece's government has begun the latest round of talks with its lenders over its bailout programme. IMF chief Poul Thomsen had coins thrown at him as he arrived at the Athens finance ministry, but was apparently unhurt.

We're also deep into the European earnings season, with a range of companies reporting this morning. The early signs are mixed -- Marks & Spencer has reported another fall in clothing and homeware sales (down 1.3% between July and September), while Primark has posted much more impressive figures. 

Insurance group RSA has warned that 'severe weather events' during 2013 have been more costly than expected. Imperial Tobacco, though, has posted higher profits and hiked its dividend by 10%. Chairman Iain Napier is stepping down too.

And security firm G4S is announcing its new strategy this morning, after a pretty dire 16 months that began with its failure to handle the London Olympic security contract.

In the economics world, we find out how Britain's service sector performed last month at 9.30am GMT -- can it match yesterday's strong performance from the construction sector?

The European Commission is also due to release updated economic growth forecasts, at 10am GMT.

And central banks will also be in focus, after the Reserve Bank of Australia voted to leave interest rates unchanged early this morning. In two days time, the European Central Bank must decide whether to react to the eurozone's falling inflation and rising unemployment, and ease monetary policy. Many economists think it should -- not all are convinced it will.

I'll be tracking all the main events though the day as usual.

Updated at 8.36am GMT
fields.bodyText: Time for a closing summary: • The European Commission lowered its growth forecast for the eurozone next year • Stock markets fell in Europe after the EC downgrade • A new OECD report on 'well-being' showed it sharply lower in Greece, Spain and Italy, but Britain scored highly • Britain's service firms posted their strongest growth in 16 years. • MPs heard that payday lenders are targeting young children with their TV adverts. • Greece's government began the latest round of talks with its lenders over its bailout programme. • Insiders say the Troika will also push for changes at Greece's defence industry, and could demand that two loss-making firms are closed • Photos: protests in Athens And on that note, it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all the comments, and we'll be back tomorrow. European markets have closed, and it has indeed been a downbeat day, not helped by the European Commission lowering its growth forecast for the eurozone, and lingering concerns about when quantitative easing will end. The closing scores were: • The FTSE 100 finished 16.78 points or 0.25% lower at 6746.84 • Germany's Dax was down 0.31% at 9009.11 • France's Cac closed 0.82% lower at4253.34 • Italy's FTSE MIB ended down 1.13% at 19,091.93 • Spain's Ibex lost 0.79% to 9795.7 On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently down 0.13% or 19 points. As we head to the close, markets are still falling back. Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said: [In Europe] the mining sector has been the best performing sector today after Chinese HSBC services data pointed to a fairly constructive outlook for the Chinese economy in the short term. But this hasn’t been enough to keep equity markets higher, as the EU downgraded its growth forecasts for the euro area in 2014, while German car maker BMW has helped drag the DAX lower after profits fell back. US markets opened lower this morning taking their lead from today’s weakness in Europe as investor’s exercised caution ahead of some key data later this week. It would appear that US markets are reluctant to push higher while investors absorb the different statements from various Fed policymakers, Here's a good piece by economist Shaun Richards about the challenges facing the European Central Bank as it prepares for its monthly meeting on monetary policy. He runs through the various options facing the ECB to address falling inflation, lacklustre growth and stubbornly high unemployment. We are experiencing an era where politicians mostly delegate economic policy to central banks who have emerged blinking into the light from the shadows where in my view they belong. Why have they done this? Well in a perversion of President John F Kennedy’s famous statement about going to the Moon they have delegated the job because it is hard, rather than being inspired. More here: Will the European Central Bank panic on Thursday? Back in Greece...troika officials faced angry protests as they left the finance ministry after their first meeting with the Greek government, hours after coins were thrown at IMF mission chief Poul Thomsen as he arrived. There were scuffles between demonstrators and police as Thomsen and colleagues left the meeting with finance minister Yannis Stournaras. Many of the protestors were ministry cleaners who face dismissal as part of Greece's cuts to its public sector. Associated Press reports that the Troika officials had to be spirited out of the building through an emergency exit, after protesting civil servants blocked the lifts and main entrance to the ministry. They had earlier tried to disrupt the meeting by chanting anti-austerity slogans outside the room where it took place America's service sector has followed Britain's by reporting that activity picked up pace in October, although the increase wasn't as dramatic. The ISM survey of service sector activity rose to 55.4, from 54.4 in September, showing activity picked up. Firms also hired more workers. But there were also signs that last month's government shutdown did hit firms, with the new orders index dropping to its lowest level since July. (a reminder - the UK service sector PMI hit 62.5 in October, the highest level since May 1997) Date for the diary - Italian Senators will vote on November 27 on whether to expel centre-right leader Silvio Berlusconi from parliament over his conviction for tax fraud, officials said (via Reuters). Time for a round-up of the main events of the day so far. • The European Commission has lowered its growth forecast for the eurozone next year, predicting that GDP will rise by just 1.1% in 2014, not 1.2%. The EC's latest Autumn Forecasts also predicted weak growth and above-target deficits in several countries worst hit by the eurozone crisis. Commissioner Olli Rehn said Europe had begun growing again, adding it was too early to claim "victory" in the financial crisis. He also warned that Slovenia must work hard to clean up its banking sector, Key points from Rehn's press conference are here. The EC also predicted that inflation will remain subdued at 1.5% in 2014 and 1.4% in 2015, adding to pressure on the European Central Bank to ease monetary policy. • The OECD has also flagged up the personal harm caused by the crisis. A new report found that 'well-being' has dived by 20% in Greece and is also sharply lower in Spain and Italy. Britain, though, scored pretty highly on its measure of places to live. • Britain's service firms have posted their strongest growth in 16 years. Activity in the dominant sector rose by the highest rate since Tony and Cherie strolled through Downing Street in May 1997. City economists say it shows the UK economy is growing strongly at present. • MPs have heard that payday lenders are targeting young children with their TV adverts, and causing a sharp rise in debt problems, at a hearing into the industry. • Greece's government has begun the latest round of talks with its lenders over its bailout programme. IMF chief Poul Thomsen had coins thrown at him as he arrived at the Athens finance ministry, but was apparently unhurt. Talks will centre on the size of Greece's fiscal gap for next year, and how it will be closed. Last night, PM Antonis Samaras ruled out pay and pension cuts, or tax rises. Insiders say the Troika will also push for changes at Greece's defence industry, and could demand that two loss-making firms are closed. • Stock markets have fallen in Europe, following the EC's lowered growth forecasts. Falling operating profits at BMW and increased storm related losses at RSA Insurance also hit the main share indices. Here's some depressing lunchtime reading -- personal well-being, and trust in our elected leaders, have both slumped in those European countries hit hardest by the financial crisis. So warns the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in a new report, which found that people in struggling eurozone countries have suffered much more than others in the developed world since the financial crisis began The OECD has reported that average life satisfaction declined by more than 20% in Greece between 2007 and 2012, 12% in Spain, and 10% in Italy. However, moderate increases were recorded in Germany (+4%), along with Israel, Russia, Mexico and Sweden. Citizens in the hardest-hit euro area countries have lost trust in their governments and institutions. the OECD added (no surprise to regular reader). The percentage of people in these countries claiming to trust national government fell by 10 percentage points between 2007 and 2012. In the OECD countries as a whole, less than half of those surveyed said they trusted their governments - the lowest level recorded since 2006. OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurría said the report should be "a wake-up call to us all”, adding: It is a reminder that the central purpose of economic policies is to improve people’s lives. We need to rethink how to place people’s needs at the heart of policy-making. While unemployment has clearly driven down life satisfaction, many people in work across Europe suffer from inadequate circumstances, the OECD found: Achieving the right balance between requirements and opportunities drives people’s commitment at work, and is key to strengthening their capacity to cope with demanding jobs. In Europe, 50% of persons who face poor work organisation and workplace relationships report that their job impairs their health, compared with only 15% among those experiencing favourable conditions. With appropriate resources and support, even highly demanding jobs can be fulfilling. But without them, the accumulation of stress factors in the workplace frequently leads to health problems. The full report is here: How's Life 2013 Perhaps more surprisingly, the OECD has declared that the UK is a great place to live and work, despite rising inequality. It found that Britain ranks above average on jobs, earnings and housing in its Better Life Index - but below average on education, skills and income equality. Economics reporter Katie Allen explains: The UK is one of best places to live and work, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, although income inequality has risen by more than in other countries since the global financial crisis struck in 2007. The Paris-based thinktank has been seeking to measure wellbeing for the 34 nations of the OECD, based on aspects of life such as incomes, education, housing and security. It says the UK ranks above the OECD country average on environmental quality, personal security, jobs and earnings and housing among other measures. It is close to average for work-life balance, but below in education and skills. More here: UK scores highly in world quality of life rankings, says OECD Reuters is reporting that European regulators are close to fining several banks for rigging Euribor -- the rate at which banks would lend to each other in euros. Barclays will apparently avoid a fine after blowing the whistle on the issue. But JP Morgan, RBS, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, SocGen and Credit Agricole all face penalties. The first fines could be announced in December, although some banks are still fighting them. Here's the snaps: 05-Nov-2013 13:12 - EXCLUSIVE-EU ANTITRUST AUTHORITY SET TO FINE JP MORGAN, RBS AND DEUTSCHE BANK FOR SUSPECTED FIXING OF EURIBOR INTEREST RATE BENCHMARK - SOURCE 05-Nov-2013 13:12 - HSBC, SOCIETE GENERALE AND CREDIT AGRICOLE WILL ALSO BE PENALISED FOR EURIBOR RIGGING - SOURCE 05-Nov-2013 13:12 - BRITAIN'S BARCLAY'S TO AVOID FINE AFTER ALERTING EUROPEAN COMMISSION TO THE SUSPECTED WRONGDOING - SOURCE 05-Nov-2013 13:12 - FINES EXPECTED TO BE AT LOW END OF COMMISSION'S LIMIT OF UP TO 10 PERCENT OF A COMPANY'S GLOBAL REVENUE 05-Nov-2013 13:12 - SOME BANKS READY TO SETTLE, WILL RECEIVE 10 PERCENT REDUCTION IN FINE, OTHERS CHALLENGING THE PENALTIES 05-Nov-2013 13:12 - FINES LIKELY TO TOTAL HUNDREDS OF MILLIONS OF EUROS WITH FIRST DECISION NEXT MONTH Martin Lewis's suggestion that payday loan adverts should be banned from children's programmes has received plenty of attention -- here's a selection, starting with a tweet from the MP for Worcester, Robin Walker: Greece's troika of lenders received a pretty rough welcome at the start of their talks with the Greek government over its bailout programme. One man has been detained by police after throwing coins at the head of the International Monetary Fund's delegation, Poul Thomsen. Our Athens correspondent, Helena Smith, reports that the man was immediately arrested after sending a barrage of coinage at the IMF mission chief's car as it arrived at the finance ministry this morning. He was driven to Athens' central police HQ - although it remains unclear as yet if he has been charged, Helena adds. The Kathimerini newspaper reports that Thomsen ducked as the volley came his way, and wasn't hit. Associated Press reports that a few dozen civil servants "armed with a bullhorn" chanted anti-austerity slogans Tuesday outside the room where the Troika officials were meeting Finance Ministry Yannis Stournaras. AP adds: Ministry officials said the protesters, who work for a Development Ministry department in the building, did not enter the room and left peacefully. European stock markets are in the red today, with traders pinning some blame on the EC's newly lowered growth forecasts. Toby Morris, senior sales trader at CMC Markets, commented: European stocks have retreated from 5 year highs after the European Commission lowered the zone’s growth forecast. The zone’s economy is expected to shrink by 0.4% this year before recovering to 1.1% in 2014, revised lower from 1.2%. The revision is a further reminder of the hurdles still facing a European recovery, expecting near record levels of unemployment to remain until 2015. Investors aren't too impressed by recent financial earnings either. I flagged up earlier that BMW had disappointed investors with a drop in operating profits. It's not alone -- as Reuters explains: Half way into the European earnings season, 52 percent of STOXX Europe 600 .STOXX companies have missed profit forecasts, and two thirds have missed revenue forecasts, according to data from Thomson Reuters StarMine, a sharp contrast with the second-quarter result season during which only 42 percent of companies missed profit forecasts. Insurance firm RSA is the biggest faller on the FTSE 100 after warning that weather-related claims will be bigger than expected. More here: RSA Insurance shares swept away after recent storms Here's the situation: FTSE 100: down 38 points at 6725, -0.5% German DAX: down 56 points at 8980, - 0.6% French CAC: down 35 points at 4253, - 0.8% Jo Swinson MP, Minister for Employment Relations and Consumer Affairs has told MPs that the voluntary code of conduct followed by payday lenders is not being complied with. She said: One in five [of people taking out a payday loan] are not asked about affordability, rising to 60% when rolling over a loan. The industry is not taking its responsibilities anywhere near as seriously as it should be doing. The OFT says the pressure it has put on the industry has removed 19 out of 50 payday lenders, and that three firms have had their licences formally revoked. Another two, unnamed firms, are at an "advanced stage" of action by the OFT (via Patrick Collinson again). More key points from the parliamentary hearing into the Payday loan industry. Debt charities and advice organisations are telling MPs that the number of people coming to them with payday loan problems has "exploded" over the past two years. Peter Tutton, head of policy at StepChange, says: We have seen an eightfold increase in the number of people with pay day loan problems. The average debt is £1,600 when the average income is £1,200. Gillian Guy, chief executive of Citizens Advice says her figures are even higher: At Citizens Advice we have seen a 10-fold increase in people coming to us with payday loan issues. Many of them are paying off the debt by taking out further debt. Our tracker survey of 3000 people [with payday loans] shows that over 60% of these people did not have adequate affordability checks when taking out a loan, and 94% of them did not have affordability checks on rollover loans. MPs have been told that children are being 'groomed' by payday lenders, according to Martin Lewis of moneysavingexpert.com, who is calling for a complete ban on advertising of the controversial loans from children's television*. My colleague Patrick Collinson reports that Lewis told the BIS committee's inquiry into payday lenders: "They have created the demand for pay day loans, and now they are saying it is what people want. Figures we are releasing this morning show that 14% of parents of under-10 year olds, when they tell their children they can't have a toy, they have the TV advert [for a loan] quoted back to them. We have normalised a niche form of lending." * UPDATE: Here's a full statement on the call for a ban from children's programmes Richard Lloyd, executive director, Which?, says its figures also show that younger adults are being drawn into payday loans: "In total, our figures suggest that 4% of the population are taking a payday loan each month, but among 18-29 year olds it is 7%." And here's a chart showing the EC's latest growth forecasts by country (sorry if it's too blurry: the original is on page 12 of this pdf) Worth noting that the EC expects the UK to grow by 2.2% next year, well ahead of the eurozone forecast of +1.1%, the EU average of +1.4%, or the 1.7% growth seen in Germany. Back to the European Commission's new economic forecasts, in which it lowered its forecast for 2014 slightly to a 1.1% rise in GDP, from 1.2%. The full report can be seen here. Commissioner Olli Rehn has just held a press conference on the report (video recording here), in which he struck an upbeat tone - saying Europe had now returned to growth. The whole report is 177 pages, and packed with detail. Brussels' correspondents, though, have been chewing through it quickly and quizzing Rehn. Peter Spiegel of the FT, and Matthew Dalton of the WSJ, have tweeted the key points: Back at the parliamentary committee hearing into Wonga and its rivals.... TV money guru Martin Lewis of moneysavingexpert.com is comprehensively attacking the payday loan industry. Lewis said: If you take 100 people seeking a loan, 99 of them can find a better and cheaper alternative than a payday loan. They are not fit for purpose... there is a desert of regulation... I'm not convinced about the ethics of the business model. People think its a financial play, but this is a technology play. It allows you, while you are pissed and want to gamble at 11.30 at night, to get a loan. It just needs to be slower... the instant, hi tech nature of how they operate is very dangerous. See 10.07am and 10.28am for earlier key points from the hearing Another sign of weakness in the eurozone economy -- producer prices (a measure of what factories charge for their goods) rose by just 0.1% in September, after being flat in August. It underlines the limited inflationary pressures across the region -- which could prompt the European Central Bank to cut interest rates on Thursday. Nick Beecroft, chairman of Saxo Capital Markets, argued last night that the ECB has all the evidence it needs: The past week has brought news of dangerously low inflation in Germany. We have also learnt that German retail sales plunged in September, Eurozone unemployment edged up by 0.2 percent to 12.2 percent and the Consumer Price Index across the Eurozone is estimated to have risen by only 0.7 percent in the past year. The euro has always had the potential to become a deflationary disaster and now it looks like Japanisation is upon the continent. Zombie banks are kept alive via the pernicious LTRO Ponzi so that they can buy their national governments’ bonds and labour reforms are proceeding at a snail’s pace. City analysts are rather impressed by the news that UK service sector has posted its strongest growth in 16 years (details here) Nida Ali, economic advisor to the Ernst & Young ITEM Club, said the the services sector has started the fourth quarter "with a bang" (makes a change from those damn fireworks): These figures beat even the most optimistic expectations, as most commentators, after strong out turns in the past couple of months, were expecting the pace of services growth to slow in October..... The strong increase in employment supports our view that the unemployment rate is on track to drop below the 7% forward guidance threshold well ahead of schedule. We expect it to move below 7% by mid-2015, a year ahead of the Bank of England's current forecast. However, given the positive developments in the last couple of months, the Bank is likely to downgrade its unemployment forecast in its next Inflation Report due next Wednesday. This will probably be accompanied with upward revisions to growth as well. Jeremy Cook, chief economist at currency brokers, World First, said: The services sector is flying. Records in both output and employment have guided the PMI to the highest level since Tony Blair took power in the UK back in 1997, as confidence around the long-term ability for recovery continues to increase. Combined with the manufacturing figure from Friday and yesterday’s 6 year record construction number, we can safely say that momentum is firmly gathering in the UK economy. The wind is very much in our sails. We would have to say that growth is now running at close to 5% on an annualised basis, on these initial estimates, and, at the moment, shows little sign of abating. We must now wait for the Bank of England’s appraisal of this run of numbers. There will be a fair few of the economic fraternity of who will be looking forward to next week’s Quarterly Inflation Report and expecting some form of outlook change from the MPC; a change that will see rates rising sooner than the 2016 expectation that was originally forecast… Andy Scott, associate director at HiFX: Following positive surprises in the manufacturing and construction sector indexes, the early indicators for the fourth quarter look like 2013 could see the economy grow at its fastest pace since before the financial crisis. Markit, the company that measures and releases the data for all three sectors, said that combining the three indexes points to GDP growth this quarter of 1.3%. This should serve to ease some concerns that have arisen over the past few weeks that the recovery won’t be sustained. The buoyancy of the housing market where prices have been rising steadily helped by increasing mortgage approvals and the government’s help to buy scheme has been what a lot of commentators have put the recovery down to but clearly it’s broader based. With unemployment continuing to fall at a modest but steady pace, confidence will be maintained which should boost consumer spending and corporate investment. And here's our full story: Service sector growing at fastest pace since 1997 Wonga has also admitted it was forced to make changes to its sales practices following an Office of Fair Trading investigation,as the hearing before MPs continued... It was told to highlight risk factors more prominently on its website and make clearer disclosures around APRs (percentage interest rates). QuickQuid and Mr Lender admits that they have been ordered by the Office of Fair Trading to change their procedures on 'roll overs' where hard-pressed borrowers ask for a loan to be rolled over at the end of the term. In total, Mr Lender admits that it was told to make around 30 changes to its procedures. Back to parliament, and MPs are pressing payday lenders on how they check whether borrowers can afford a payday loan. Adam Freeman, chief executive of Mr Lender, admits that it has no idea if a borrower is taking out new loans from Wonga or other lenders at the same time. He gives an example of a person taking home £1,500 a month with £600 left after rent and other expenses. We might then lend them £300 or £350. But we don't know if at the same time they have gone to Wonga for a loan. Wonga's head of public affaris Henry Raine says it uses 'raw data' from agency Call Credit to assess borrowers and, without explaining further, says "we look at how people interact with the slides and the screen." (via Patrick Collinson - whose first report from the BIS committee is here) While Britain's service sector is booming (see here), the eurozone economy is weaker than Brussels had hoped. The European Commission has trimmed its growth forecast for 2014 to +1.1%, down from +1.2%, admitting that private demand and investment will not increase as much as it had hoped. The growth rate is expected to rise to 1.7% in 2015. It also sees little end to Europe's jobless crisis, predicting that the eurozone unemployment rate will hit 12.2% for 2013, remain there in 2014, before dipping to 11.8% in 2015. Olli Rehn, commissioner for economic affairs, commented: There are increasing signs that the European economy has reached a turning point, But it is too early to declare victory: unemployment remains at unacceptably high levels. That's why we must continue working to modernise the European economy. The EC's latest report also predicts that public debt levels across the eurozone will peak at 95.9% of GDP next year, up from 95.5% in 2015. The annual deficit for the euro area is expected to drop to 2.5% in 2014, and then to 2.4% in 2015, from 3.1% this year. But annual borrowing levels will be higher in many of the countries worst affected by the crisis -- where economies were driven into deep recessions by tough austerity policies. Here's the details: • EU COMMISSION FORECASTS FRENCH DEFICIT AT 4.1% OF GDP IN 2013, 3.8% IN 2014, 3.7% IN 2015 • EU COMMISSION FORECASTS ITALIAN DEFICIT AT 3.0% OF GDP IN 2013, 2.7% IN 2014, 2.5% IN 2015 •EU COMMISSION FORECASTS SPANISH DEFICIT AT 6.8% OF GDP IN 2013, 5.9% IN 2014, 6.6% IN 2015 •EU COMMISSION FORECASTS GREEK DEFICIT AT 13.5% OF GDP IN 2013, 2.0% IN 2014, 1.1% IN 2015 • EU COMMISSION FORECASTS PORTUGUESE DEFICIT AT 5.9% OF GDP IN 2013, 4.0% IN 2014, 2.5% IN 2015 •EU COMMISSION FORECASTS CYPRUS DEFICIT AT 8.3% OF GDP IN 2013, 8.4% IN 2014, 6.3% IN 2015 Sony Kapoor of the ReDefine thinktank tweets that the forecasts show that European leaders should not be talking about the crisis being over, even though the risk of the euro breaking up has receded. As expected, Wonga has been defending itself before the Business, Innovation and Skills select committee (the grilling is being streamed here): My colleague Patrick Collinson has the details: Wonga's head of regulatory and public affairs, Henry Raine, told a select committee of MPs this morning that only 9% of its 1.25m customers fail to repay loans, and that the vast majority of its customers repay take moderate sized loans (£270 on average) and that only one in 15 roll over their loans. The committee hearings come after the premiere last night of Wonga's feature length film portraying happy customers. More details of the film is here.... Stella Creasy, now Labour's shadow minister for competition and consumer affairs, said this morning the film should perhaps be called "Legal loansharking is a Wonderful Life" (Patrick continues) She said: “Wonga may be able to find twelve people to say they are happy customers, I can find 1200 who are not and who are now paying the price for borrowing from these legal loan sharks. They like to claim they are different from other payday lenders, but the truth is they are all as bad as each other. That isn't my review, but the outcome of the Office of Fair Trading investigation which found the entire payday lending industry in Britain was out of control. That’s why they have written to 50 legal loan sharks including Wonga about their behaviour. If Wonga really want to be transparent about how they make a million pounds a week from lending to hard pressed Brits, they should own up to being warned by the OFT and spell out what they are doing to put that right, rather than filling our cinema screens with such fiction.” Over to Greece again... where our correspondent Helena Smith says behind the scenes Greek officials are expressing concerns that the country’s ailing defence industries are going to be the real rubbing point when negotiations with its lenders begin at noon (see details here) While much of the saga over resumption of talks has focused on the reluctance of the government to enact any more “horizontal cuts,” officials privately admit that the real issue is the pressure creditors are exerting on Athens to close the country’s ailing defence industries. Lenders had demanded that two notoriously loss-making armaments firms, the Hellenic Defense Systems (EAS) and the Hellenic Vehicle Industry (ELVO), as well as a mining company, LARCO, be shut down back in September – seeing the closures as “prior actions” that were necessary to unlock the next tranche of aid – at 1 bn euro vital to paying public sector pay checks and pensions. Apparently incensed that the government has followed through with neither action, they have signalled that the closures will be the focus of today’s finance ministry talks. “It’s the real sticking point because it will mean the loss of thousands of jobs,” said one source at the ministry. “They basically want us to streamline EAS to the point that we only have one factory left that can produce kit for our own army but not enough to export abroad.” As south east Europe’s only EU member state, government officials say it is a “matter of pride” that the Hellenic Defense Industry is kept alive. “As an issue it’s much hotter than most people think because it’s one of national pride.” Stunning results from the UK service industry -- activity across the dominant sector has hit its fastest rate in 16 years. Markit reported that the monthly service sector PMI soared to 62.5 in October, up from September's 60.3, and well ahead of economists' forecasts for a fall to 59.8. Markit said it shows that UK recovery was gathering pace. We've also had strong results from the manufacturing and construction industries for last month -- showing record increases in output, employment, new business and backlogs of work. In total, it suggests that the UK economy is currently growing at a remarkably strong quarterly rate of 1.3%, Markit said, up sharply from previous quarters (UK GDP rose by 0.% in the last quarter). Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit, said: The UK economic recovery moved up a gear again in October. Manufacturing, services and construction all continued to see very strong rates of expansion, pointing to an ongoing broad-based upturn. However it is the services sector which, due to its sheer size, is the major driving force. Service sector activity hasn't risen this strongly since May 1997..... The news sent the pound romping higher, up 0.5% or 0.7 of a cent against the US dollar, to $1.604. Such strong data may encourage the Bank of England to raise its growth forecasts -- and could also bring an interest rate rise closer. Here's some instant reaction: The full report on October's PMI report is here. Hopes that the Spanish labour market is healing have been dealt a blow this morning, with the news that the jobless total rose by 87,028 in October. Seasonal factors are to blame, as the tourism season came to a close. But the increase is worse than the 82,500 increase that some analysts expected, even though Spain's recession may be over. On a more positive note, though, the jobless total looks to be lower than a year ago: Heads-up: the parliamentary Business, Innovation and Skills committee has begun its hearing into the UK payday loans industry. It's being streamed live here: Committee chair Adrian Bailey has asked Wonga, QuickQuid and Mr Lender to explain why they have such a bad reputation..... We'll have the answers shortly. Payday lender Wonga got its retaliation in first last night, ahead of the parliamentary hearing in payday lenders which begins at 9.15am GMT (so in 15 minutes). Here's the details: Chief operating officer Niall Wass warned against "jumping to conclusions" about his company, which has come under fire over the way it treats customers. "I am not sitting here today saying that everything we do is perfect; what we are trying to do is use great technology to give a really fair, transparent service to customers," he said in an interview with ITV News At 10. Wass challenged the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev Justin Welby, who has criticised the payday loan companies, to use Wonga services. "What I am asking him and others to do – go use the service, see if you think it is fair and transparent, take out £30 for 10 days, pay it back after a week and then judge us by our customers," he said. His remarks came as Wonga made a film showing the positive experience of the "silent majority" of its customers, ahead of a session in the House of Commons when MPs will question payday loan companies. Representatives from Wonga, QuickQuid and Mr Lender – three of the biggest payday lending firms – will appear before the Commons Business, Innovation and Skills Select Committee. MPs are expected to follow up on a damning report by the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) which found "deep-rooted" problems in the way payday loans attract and treat customers. More here: Wonga defends its 'fair, transparent service' ahead of committee hearing Worth noting that Wonga will be represented by its top PR man -- Henry Raine, head of regulatory and public affairs, rather than CEO Errol Damelin, or Wass. Elsewhere in the corporate world, and hundreds of jobs are at risk at G4S as the security firms looks to rebuild its fortunes. CEO Ashley Almanza told reporters this morning that between 250 and 400 jobs at its 'UK cash business' will be cut over the next 18 months. He also explains that 35 G4S businesses have been identified as under-performing -- the company will now decide whether to invest in them, shake them up, or sell them off. As Reuters reports: • G4S CEO SAYS 250-400 JOBS IN UK CASH BUSINESS TO BE CUT OVER NEXT 18 MONTHS • G4S SAYS 35 BUSINESSES GLOBALLY IDENTIFIED AS UNDERPERFORMING, WILL NOW DECIDE WHETHER TO GROW, RESTRUCTURE OR EXIT THEM • G4S GFS.L CEO SAYS CONFIDENT WILL RESTORE COMPANY'S REPUTATION IN UK The shake-up comes a day after the Serious Fraud Office announced it was holding a criminal investigation into the electronic offender tagging contract run by G4S and Serco, following claims that they billed for monitoring people who were back in prison, outside the UK, or deceased.
